rave 0.1.9

R6 Class to Load 'fst' Files

LazyFST.Rd

provides hybrid data structure for 'fst' file

Methods

  • LazyFST$open()

  • LazyFST$close()

  • LazyFST$save()

  • LazyFST$new()

  • LazyFST$clone()

to be compatible with LazyH5

...

ignored

none

Usage

...

ignored

to be compatible with LazyH5

Method new()

constructor

Usage

LazyFST$new(file_path, transpose = FALSE, dims = NULL, ...)

Arguments

file_path

where the data is stored

transpose

whether to load data transposed

dims

data dimension, only support 1 or 2 dimensions

...

ignored

Usage

LazyFST$get_dims(...)

Arguments

ignored

Returns

vector, dimensions

Method subset()

subset data

Usage

LazyFST$subset(i = NULL, j = NULL, ..., drop = TRUE)

Arguments

i, j, ...

index along each dimension

drop

whether to apply drop the subset

Returns

subset of data

Method clone()

The objects of this class are cloneable with this method.

Usage

LazyFST$clone(deep = FALSE)

Arguments

deep

Whether to make a deep clone.

Examples


# Data to save, total 8 MB
x <- matrix(rnorm(1000000), ncol = 100)

# Save to local disk
f <- tempfile()
fst::write_fst(as.data.frame(x), path = f, compress = 100)

# Load via LazyFST
dat <- LazyFST$new(file_path = f, dims = c(10000, 100))

pryr::object_size(dat)
#> Registered S3 method overwritten by 'pryr':
#>   method      from
#>   print.bytes Rcpp
#> 120 kB
#> 236 kB

# Check whether the data is identical
range(dat[] - x)
#> [1] 0 0

# The reading of column is very fast
system.time(dat[,100])
#>    user  system elapsed 
#>   0.055   0.001   0.013 

# Reading rows might be slow
system.time(dat[1,])
#>    user  system elapsed 
#>   0.065   0.010   0.025
